On Feb 17, 2008 6:46 PM, Steve Bjorg <steveb@...> wrote:
> Composeable URIs are generally not well regarded as they lead to brittle
> structures.  Instead, URIs should be "built" from templates or discovered by
> exploring the state graph.  A good example is the Atom specification, which
> annotates entries with edit links.  It's clean.  It's machine discoverable.
> And it allows for changes in future URI structures without breaking the
> client.  That's the way it should be!


This is true, but it does no harm for structures to be transparent to
the user.  This scheme of putting the breadcrumb in the path strikes
me as elegant and clean from a UI perspective, since it satisfies the
user goal of maintaining a mental model of the information hierarchy
they are navigating.
